H0.text: when did movies start coming out in color. 1908

H1.text: when did movies start coming out in color. 1915

H2.text: when did movies start coming out in color. 1920

H3.text: when did movies start coming out in color. 1895

A4.text: Kinemacolor was first shown to the public in 1909.

A5.text: Kinemacolor was used commercially from 1909 to 1915.

A6.text: Kinemacolor film subjects were catalogued in 1913.

A7.text: On with the Show! (1929) (the first all-talking color feature)

A8.text: Redskin (1929), with a synchronized score, and The Mysterious Island (1929), a part-talkie, were photographed almost entirely in this process also but included some sequences in black and white.

A9.text: Beginning in 1932, Technicolor introduced a new full-color process

A10.text: Technicolor, originally also a two-color process capable of only a limited range of hues, was commercialized in 1922 and soon became the most widely used of the several two-color processes available in the 1920s.
